bibl.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to Thomas F. Bayard, September 8, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: Hon Thos F. Bayard Secretary of State Wasington D.C.
Sir: I received a letter from the Treasury Department informing me that I was due to the Government of the U.S. for service as Vice Consul General of the U.S. at Monrovia Liberia $337.27.

Your government charged me for the burial expenses of Moses A. Hopkins that I am willing to bear. Your government also harge me for paying a bill of Mrs E. J. Jarmon of Cape Palmos after telling me to do so. Please look over your consular series and you will see here the Department told me to do what Minister Smyth and Hopkins id not do. The bill due Mrs. Harmon as $48. and some cents and I paid in the U.S. draft. Your Government lso charged me $30.00 which I aid the U.S. Messenger who could not

seek the position; but being acquainted with Moses A. Hopkins and knowing he was in a place unknown to him I thought I would be of use to hime therefore I took the position and even held it long before ever receiving a certificate of recognition as Vice Consul Genl from your peer; therefore how now can your government be so exact on me after laboring under many disadvantages in its behalf? I pray your government gives me what due me. I know you will consider my case as I have
State there. Please do all you can for me. I am not going back to Liberia; so I will not be able to give you any vouchers.
Hoping you will do justice to my case- and hoping to hear from you soon
I remain Dear Sir Your obedient Servant
Samuel S. Sevier Franklinton Franklin Co N. C.
